answer_html: So the average value of \(1/x\) on the interval \([1,e]\) is \((e - 1)^{-1}\).
answer_latex: So the average value of $1/x$ on the interval $[1,e]$ is $(e - 1)^{-1}$.
hints_html:
What is the definition for the average value of a function, \(f(x)\), on an interval, \([a,b]\)?

See the related wikipedia article. Note that mean and average have the same meaning in this context.

{wikipedia

hints_raw:
What is the definition for the average value of a function, <math>f(x)</math>, on an interval, <math>[a,b]</math>?

See the related [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean#Mean_of_a_function wikipedia article]. Note that mean and average have the same meaning in this context.
question: 1 (e)
sols_html:
This is simple matter of evaluating an integral. From the definition of the average value of a function on an interval, we can write an expression for the average value of \(1/x\) on the interval \([1,e]\):

\[\begin{aligned} f_{avg} &= \frac{1}{e - 1}\int_{1}^{e}\frac{1}{x}\,dx \\ &= \frac{1}{e - 1}\ln(x)\Big\vert_{1}^{e} \\f_{avg} &= \frac{1}{e - 1}\end{aligned}\]

So the average value of \(1/x\) on the interval \([1,e]\) is \((e - 1)^{-1}\).
statement_html:
Compute the average value of

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac1{x}\end{aligned}\]

over the interval 1 \(\leq\) x \(\leq\) e.
statement_raw:
Compute the average value of

:<math> f(x) = \frac1{x} </math>

over the interval 1 ≤ ''x'' ≤ ''e''.
